instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1304: What is A1304? A1304 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Mid 2009 with EMC 2334, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2375..
definitions.820-2375: What is 820-2375? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP1V05_S5: What is PP1V05_S5? PP1V05_S5 is a 1.05v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. On 2008-2009 15” and 17” Macbook boards, this often gets stuck at 0.3v due to a bad C7771 capacitor. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1304</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2375</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi,
I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1304</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2375</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, that has no power. I think that the problem may be in the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, that seams to low, but i'm not sure.

I get the following voltages:

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PP18V5_G3H</SIGNAL> - 19V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 19.5V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_R_G3H</SIGNAL>  - 8.4V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  - 8.4V

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1304</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2375</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looks good.
MCP platform starts only pressing power button.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1304</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2375</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
OK.
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5</SIGNAL> - 1.09V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0.1V

I think that it is the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, am I right? If so, where from here?

On pin 21 of the <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> i get 3.4V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1304</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2375</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Diode mode to ground at L7620?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1304</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2375</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1304</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2375</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1304</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2375</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1304</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2375</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Good enough to get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> at L7620.
If not, check all surrounding resistors.
You may need to change <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and/or <TRANSISTOR>Q7620</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1304</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2375</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Hi, now i have 3.3V on  L7620, but still no power

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1304</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2375</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Press power button first.
Check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> at same time.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1304</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2375</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
I don't have a drop pulse on  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>  (3.4V steady).
Can it be the power button? How can i power it from the board?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1304</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2375</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Use the logic...
Solder an wire to <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> line.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1304</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2375</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
With the  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> trigger it power its on.
I wanted to make sure if the problem is the button, or the connector, but can't figure out witch pin on the connector enables the power on. Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1304</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2375</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1304</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2375</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi,
Ii seams that it powers on (it has fan spin), but i don't get any image, even on external monitor, and don't have any USB activity (PEN doesn't blink).
CPU gets hot, and i get voltages on all big coils...
Any idea?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1304</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2375</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Try known good BIOS.

What did you change to fix <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> problem?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1304</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2375</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi. 
I didn't change anything yet.  Just conected and disconected the cables, made some measures, and it starts working by it self...
Do you have an known good BIOS (I have one, but not sure if it is good?
